specs/ussuri/approved/cyborg-api.rst.message: We should also have 'device ID', 'vendor name', substring of model name, etc. But they could be implemented over multiple patches if needed.

We can apply filter only with the field defined in Device table,and Device object. Otherwise, we should manage a mapping relation between the input like vendor_name to vendor ID, or substring of mode name to model.
Why is this not a PATCH on 'enabled' field? We then don't need enabled and disabled forms.
also, since we need a status for the device, do we need add a status column in the device database table?
just a suggestion for all this spec, I don't think we should add accelerator in the api url. here accelerator is just a url path not include in the api path. so /v2/devices/ is more suitable.

I have concern with a problem related to a possibility of unsynchronization between the Cyborg's DB(status) and the Placement's DB(reserved).

There is an another way to realize enable/disable API, using reserved field in placement as the only one original data, IMO.

This is simple way because that doesn't effect current cyborg DB scheme, and doesn't cause a unsynchronize problem.

But, on the other hand,your way has a pros, can add "maintenance_reason", like models.py in ironic[1].
What is your opinion about this?

I was thinking that operator should be able to see the devices' status. If we don't have this field, we should invoke placement API to see if the device is enabled or not, which may cause latency.  
For the unsync issue you mention above, could you pls give an example? I was thinking that we can update 'status' field and call placement API in same Device API call.

Your concern about latency is right, that is cons of the simple way.
In performance sensitive case, operators need to access Placement DB directly.

The consistency between Cyborg and Placement could be kept in normal scenario.
My concern, inconsistency, will be happen in exception scenario, e.g. cyborg invokes Placement API and will down before receiving the result.
In this case, Cyborg's db is not updated, but Placement's DB is updated.
To avoid this, like 2-phase commit is a way, but it may be little overdoing in this purpose.

I think both methods has each pros/cons, and to decide this, we should think a priority, between performance and simplicity.

etc/proxy-server.conf-sample.message:
I think we should expand this comment, it's a bit vague as is, leaving some un-answered quetions.

"only" new clusters are supported?
what happens if it's enabled for an existing cluster? 
When the default changes, will it support existing clusters too?

Seconding this. Maybe something like

> Use symlinks to point to current versions in the archive container. This reduces data movement and removes race conditions that could lead to data loss when overwriting and deleting versioned data at a cost of increased time-to-first-byte on read. Note that this has impacts on usage stats and container quotas. Default is false to match preexisting behavior, but this may change in a future release.

As for your questions, my understanding is:

Existing clusters can use this too, provided operators and users are aware of and expecting the new behavior.

Enabling it for an existing cluster makes all of the existing versioned containers behave like they were freshly-enabled. That is to say, when a new write comes in, we
- check if the current version is a VW symlink, see that it isn't,
- transfer it to the archive container,
- let the client write to the archive container, and
- drop a link to the new write in the primary container.

So on the whole, it should be pretty seamless whenever we get around to switching the default. It's just a matter of setting expectations appropriately.

I'm...not sure whether I like this or not. On the one hand, it more-closely mirrors the pre-symlink behavior. On the other,

- I'd generally expect that turning off versioning should stop writes going to the archive container; this breaks that expectation.
- The data in the archive container may have been overwritten, bringing back questions about what we can/should do for POSTs to "broken" static links.

In particular, being able to POST X-Delete-After: 1 to an object in the archive container (where you don't necessarily have write access)... it makes me a little nervous.

From a user's perspective using symlinks or not and where the data actually resides should be irrelevant. Even if the user turned off versioning. The obj that he/she has access to read and write, should still allow him to POST also. The behavior from the user's POV should be seamless.

Just to be clear what's going on here (because by next week I will probably have forgotten).  Which python is used by tox is controlled by tox.ini.  But, that python needs to actually be available on the node running the job in order for the job to succeed.  At this point, we can assume that 3.6 will be available everywhere (this is guaranteed by openstack-infra).  But 3.7 is still problematic (don't ask me why).  So for this job that we want running in py3.7, we need to (a) specify a nodeset for which py3.7 is available, and (b) tell the job to make sure it's available (i.e., install it if necessary).  So that's the point of these two lines.

For those two lines to actually work, the 'ensure-python' role must be present in the job playbook (which is also added in this patch).  It consumes the 'python_version' variable; if that's unset, it just makes sure python is available (and the system python3 will be py3.6).

So that's what's going on here.

Another option is we should include one more import parameter --all-stores and if both --stores or --all-stores is specified then we should reject the request.

I think this name is too vague.  Take a look at the sample import json you give below:

  {"method": {"name":"glance-direct"},
   "stores": ["ceph1", "ceph2"],
   "allow_failure": true }

The "allow_failure" isn't part of the "stores" value, so it's not obvious that it applies only to the stores.  I suggest using "all_stores_must_succeed" with a default value of true.

I know that reverses the logic of your design, and I apologize for that.  But the advantage of doing it this way is that it covers the case that should definitely fail, that is, when all stores fail.  When a user has "allow_failure" : true and all stores fail, the call is going to fail, even though we've said it's OK to allow failure.  Saying "all_stores_must_succeed" is more clear.

Just to be clear, I agree with you that the default should be the entire call fails if any of its parts fail.  It's just a matter of how we express this in the API.
I do like that longer, more verbose name. That makes it easier to understand what the intent is and doesn't require that the caller understand the larger context behind the call.

I proposed "allow_failure" because I thought it was concise and I couldn't find a better name at that time.
The use case you describe is indeed confusing. 
Maybe we should talk of the name change during glance meeting to ensure everyone agrees and I don't need to rollback the specs?

I really didn't like this on the first reading, but I think there are some advantages to this.
(1) no DB change for a 'messages' element on the image
(2) we don't have to include these in the image schema, so they aren't required on a normal image response
(3) the image owner has full CRUD on these, so they can be deleted by the end user after their usefulness is over

But (3) brings up a point, namely, what if some joker does an image update and changes the value of this property?  Hopefully glance isn't actually using it to keep track of the stores, so it could be just overwritten with the correct list when the next store being processed succeeds.

What is your intent for os_glance_importing_to_stores at the end of the import flow?  I think it should be deleted when empty.  Same with os_glance_failed_import -- there's no reason for an empty one of these to be on an image.

Stores can be built on the fly becaused it's based on locations as you said. If we don't store the list in the database we won't be able to rebuild it.

Maybe there is another solution, we could use the "status" in the locations of the image. When we begin to import in a new store, we add it in the locations with a status of "importing". If it fails, we set status to "fail" or "active" in case of success.

I added these properties after a suggestion in a weekly meeting, but I'm not sure we really need them as a standard to follow progress already exist: users can subscribe to notifications as we send a status for each store we want to upload data to (before and after doing it).
For your point (3), if a user updates a property, we won't be able (in the current implementation) to overwrite it with the correct list as we don't store it. After the import workflow is created, we don't have access to the list anymore as each _ImportToStore task only knows it store.
We can delete the properties at the end of the process, but if I remember correctly, I think Erno suggested to keep "os_glance_failed_import" so that the user can investigate on why the upload failed in the stores contained in this list.

I just looked back at how we populate the 'stores' element on an image.  It's defined in the schema, but the description specifically says 'Store in which image data resides.  Only present when the operator has enabled multiple stores.  May be a comma-separated list of store identifiers.' and it's specified in the schema as read-only.  It doesn't correspond to anything in the database (it's populated by glance reading the store_ids from the image locations), so it's very lightweight.  I think we could do something like that here, although if we make it read-only, the end user won't be able to delete it, which I think would be bad (we want the user to be able to make the failure list disappear).  Anyway, something to think about.

Lets be consistent on the key naming and use 'all_stores'.
(Also :%s/all-stores/all_stores/g :P )
Typo, thanks.

As it is atm. this applies only to the scope of configured stores of the glance-api the request hits, not necessarily to all the stores that has configured deployment wide.

In short this would import the image to the same set of stores that the info call returns from the same glance-api. We might need to explain this behaviour in detail in the documentation.
